fields.headline: Room 101 – TV review
fields.bodyText: I like Richard Osman (massive fan of Pointless), but I very much disagree with his views, on Room 101 (BBC1), about "zoo filler". He says you only go to the zoo to see lions, tigers, monkeys, penguins and now – presumably because of a certain price-comparison website – meerkats. I went to London zoo with my son the other day; we could take or leave the cats, to be honest. One of us – the right one – most appreciated (light) petting a goat. And we both very much enjoyed the snakes and lizards. Snakes are even better if you go to a zoo where they're a bit less worried about upsetting children. I remember an afternoon in Sri Lanka, watching snakes being fed live chicks. They go on cheep-cheeping as they go down. Also, Richard, have you really ever seen a pike (the freshwater fish) in a zoo? "Yes," @richardosman tells me. (Isn't that the brilliant thing about Twitter, that you can ask people off the telly stupid questions?) Well, I think he's lying. Anyway, Frank Skinner spares Richard's "zoo filler" and mythical pike, and quite rightly puts comedian @roisinconaty's Bambi in Room 101 instead, though I don't agree with her reasons. She thinks children should be protected from death and the horrors of the world. I would very happily take my son to Colombo zoo (much cheaper entrance than London, too). Otherwise, it's a nice opener to the new series (number 14, can you believe it?). The other guest is Joan Bakewell – it's not often you get octogenarian ladies on comedy panel shows. And that should be applauded. One tiny moan on the subject of applause: I think panel-show contestants should be discouraged from applauding each other (there's a bit of that going on here), or even laughing at each other's jokes. It's both over-polite and a little bit smug: "Oh you're so funny." "No, you're so funny." That's what the audience is there for: to laugh and applaud, if they feel like it. I'd maybe put that into Room 101, if I went on. Otherwise very good, carry on.
